paper_abstract: Using exhaustive computer search we show that sorting 15 elements requires 42 comparisons, and that for n < 47 there is no algorithm of the following form: "m and n - m elements are sorted using the Ford-Johnson algorithm first, then the sorted sequences are merged", whose total number of used comparisons is smaller than the number of comparisons used by the Ford-Johnson algorithm to sort n elements directly. (c) 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
paper_title: The Ford-Johnson algorithm still unbeaten for less than 47 elements
